clinical_classes.C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

diagnosis: Visual inspection and palpation for clinical class
Duplex ultrasound for anatomic and pathophysiologic components
History for etiology (prior DVT, family history, congenital)
treatment: C2: Conservative or intervention based on symptoms
C5-C6: Active treatment of underlying disease essential

definition.@value: A standardized classification system for chronic venous disorders that describes the Clinical manifestation, Etiologic factors, Anatomic distribution, and Pathophysiologic mechanisms of venous disease.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Apply CEAP classification to describe chronic venous disease
Identify etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology components
Use basic and advanced CEAP appropriately
clinical_pearls: Always specify 's' (symptomatic) or 'a' (asymptomatic) after C class
C4 is divided into a (pigmentation/eczema), b (lipodermatosclerosis/atrophie blanche), c (corona phlebectatica)
C5 patients need surveillance - 50% recurrence rate for ulcers
Document CEAP for each limb independently
